# Letâ€™s start by fitting a multiple linear regression model with the attitude dataset, available is base R, to predict the overall rating by employees of their organization with the remaining variables (handling of employee complaints, special privileges, opportunity of learning, raises, a feedback considered too critical and opportunity of advancement).
```{r}
data("attitude")
model <- lm(rating ~ ., data = attitude)
```

```{r}
summary(model)$coefficients
```

# Extract the estimates and standard errors for the intercept and the "complaints" variable
```{r}
summary(model)$coefficients[c("(Intercept)", "complaints"), c("Estimate", "Std. Error")]
```

# Extract the p-value for the "learning" variable
```{r}
summary(model)$coefficients["learning", "Pr(>|t|)"]
```

# We can explore a reduction of the number of parameters with the reduce_parameters() function.
```{r}
library(parameters)
```

```{r}
reduce_parameters(model, method = "PCA") %>%
  parameters()
```

```{r}
pca <- principal_components(insight::get_predictors(model), n = "auto")
pca
```

```{r}
newdata <- predict(pca)
newdata$rating <- attitude$rating
```

```{r}
update(model, rating ~ PC1, data = newdata) %>%
  parameters()
```

```{r}
library(psych)
# Fit the PCA
pca <- model_parameters(psych::principal(attitude, nfactors = 1))
pca
```

```{r}
df <- cbind(attitude, predict(pca))

update(model, rating ~ PC1, data = df) %>%
  model_parameters()
```
